actions-list.actionItem: The House adjourned. The next meeting is scheduled for 10:00 a.m. on April 29, 2025.
On motion to adjourn Agreed to by voice vote.
Ms. Kaptur moved that the House do now adjourn.
The House has concluded all anticipated legislative business and has proceeded to Special Order speeches.
The House proceeded with further one minute speeches.
The House observed a moment of silence in remembrance of the Honorable John LaFalce.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: (2/3 required): 409
actions-list.actionItem: 2 (Roll no. 104).
Considered as unfinished business. S. 146 — "To require covered platforms to remove nonconsensual intimate visual depictions, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: (2/3 required): 365
actions-list.actionItem: 42 (Roll no. 103).
Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 973 — "To establish consumer standards for lithium-ion batteries."
The Chair announced that the unfinished business was the question on motions to suspend the rules, which had been debated earlier and on which further proceedings had been postponed.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of April 28.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is scheduled for approximately 6:30 P.M. today.

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 859.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
Mr. Bilirakis moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 859 — "To require the disclosure of a camera or recording capability in certain internet-connected devices."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 906.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Bilirakis moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 906 — "To direct the Federal Communications Commission to publish a list of entities that hold authorizations, licenses, or other grants of authority issued by the Commission and that have certain foreign ownership, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 2449.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Bilirakis moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 2449 — "To direct the Federal Communications Commission to establish a task force to be known as the "6G Task Force", and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 2399.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Bilirakis moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 2399 — "To require the Federal Communications Commission to establish a vetting process for prospective applicants for high-cost universal service program funding."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 866.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Bilirakis moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 866 — "To direct the Secretary of Commerce, acting through the Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Communications and Information, to conduct a study of the national security risks posed by consumer routers, modems, and devices that combine a modem and router, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 2482.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
Mr. Bilirakis moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 2482 — "To reauthorize the National Telecommunications and Information Administration, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 2444.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Bilirakis moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 2444 — "To establish a critical supply chain resiliency and crisis response program in the Department of Commerce, and to secure American leadership in deploying emerging technologies, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 2458.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Bilirakis moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 2458 — "To amend the Secure and Trusted Communications Networks Act of 2019 to prohibit the Federal Communications Commission from granting a license or United States market access for a geostationary orbit satellite system or a nongeostationary orbit satellite system, or an authorization to use an individually licensed earth station or a blanket-licensed earth station, if the license, grant of market access, or authorization would be held or controlled by an entity that produces or provides any covered communications equipment or service or an affiliate of such an entity, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 1721.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Bilirakis moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 1721 — "To direct the Secretary of Commerce to conduct a study on the feasibility of manufacturing in the United States products for critical infrastructure sectors, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 2480.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Bilirakis moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 2480 — "To require SelectUSA to coordinate with State-level economic development organizations to increase foreign direct investment in semiconductor-related manufacturing and production."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 1479.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Bilirakis moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 1479 — "To prohibit unfair and deceptive advertising of prices for hotel rooms and other places of short-term lodging, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on S. 146.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
Mr. Bilirakis moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. S. 146 — "To require covered platforms to remove nonconsensual intimate visual depictions, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 1442.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
Mr. Bilirakis moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 1442 — "To ban the sale of products with a high concentration of sodium nitrite to individuals, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 1402.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Bilirakis moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 1402 — "To require sellers of event tickets to disclose comprehensive information to consumers about ticket prices and related fees, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 973.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
Mr. Bilirakis moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 973 — "To establish consumer standards for lithium-ion batteries."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 617.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
Mr. Bilirakis moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 617 — "To amend the Visit America Act to promote music tourism, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 452.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Davidson moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 452 — "To award 3 Congressional Gold Medals to the members of the 1980 U.S. Olympic Men's Ice Hockey Team, in recognition of their extraordinary achievement at the 1980 Winter Olympics where, being comprised of amateur collegiate players, they defeated the dominant Soviet hockey team in the historic "Miracle on Ice", revitalizing American morale at the height of the Cold War, inspiring generations and transforming the sport of hockey in the United States."
The Speaker announced that votes on suspensions, if ordered, will be postponed until a time to be announced.
The House proceeded with one minute speeches.
The Chair designated Mr. Wilson of SC to lead the Members in reciting the Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag.
The Speaker announced approval of the Journal.  Pursuant to clause 1, rule I, the Journal stands approved.
Today's prayer was offered by the House Chaplain, Chaplain Margaret Grun Kibben.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of April 28.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is scheduled for 2:00 P.M. today.
The House proceeded with Morning-Hour Debate. At the conclusion of Morning-Hour, the House will recess until 2:00 p.m. for the start of legislative business.
The Speaker designated the Honorable Mariannette Miller-Meeks to act as Speaker pro tempore for today.
The House convened, starting a new legislative day.
